教学目的要求
通过本课程的学习，使学生掌握三维流形拓扑学的基本理论和方法，了解该领域当前的发展概况。

预修课程

第三章 Seifert流形、双曲3-流形与JSJ分解（6学时）

4.Allen Hatcher, Notes on basic 3-manifold topology.

Knot Theory and its Ramification》等上发表多篇研究论文三十余篇。近五年承担的科研项目有国家自然科学基金海外合作（延续）项目、国家自然科学基金海外合作项目、国家自然科学基金重点项目（参加）等。

教学目的要求
本课程是计算数学和应用数学专业的有限元方法强化课程。近半个世纪以来，有限元方法无论在数学理论上还是在实践上都得到了长足的发展。 在具有了有限元方法的基本数学基础之后， 本课程有针对性的精选一些前沿专题对学生进行强化训练，这有助于进一步增强学生的有限元理论基础并扩展学生的专业视野，为将来从事相关方向研究工作打下良好专业基础。
要求学生具有Sobolev空间，逼近论等有限元方法的基础理论知识。

预修课程
有限元方法的数学基础、泛函分析、索伯列夫空间

教材

主要内容
不连续Galerkin (DG)方法，抛物问题有限元方法，
有限元的后验误差估计和自适应方法等。

Teubner, Chichester, 1996.

高维生物统计数据分析

课程编码：011M7006H 英文名称：Analysis of High-Dimensional Biostatistical Data 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：马双鸽

教学目的要求
Biostatistics is an important subfield of statistics. The relevant scientific areas include clinical trials, genetics, public health, biomedicine, and others. Many recently collected biostatistical data are high dimensional, with the number of variables potentially far exceeding the sample size. In addition, many biostatistical datasets do not have interchangeable variables, and it is critical to model the interconnections among variables and account for such interconnections in modeling.

预修课程
advanced statistical estimation and inference; basic biology; statistical computing.

教材

主要内容
In this lecture series, I will introduce statistical methods designed for the analysis of high-dimensional biostatistical data. The main topics to be covered will include:
1. Background on biomedical studies that generate high-dimensional data. Special attention will be paid to cancer genetic data.
2. Individual variable based marginal analysis. The focus will be on multiple comparison adjustment.
3. Individual variable based joint analysis. Both dimension reduction and variable selection methods will be introduced.
4. System-based analysis including group analysis and network-based analysis.
5. Special topics including robust analysis methods and interaction analysis.
The lectures will cover methodology, computation, and application. Important theoretical results will also be discussed.

统计机器学习及其应用

课程编码：011M7007H 英文名称：Statistical Machine Learning and its Applications 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：刘玉峰

教学目的要求
Statistical machine learning is an interdisciplinary research area which is closely related to statistics, computer sciences, engineering, artificial intelligence, and bioinformatics. Many statistical machine learning techniques and algorithms are very useful for various scientific areas. In particular, modern technology enables us to gather data in large volume and complexity. Analysis of such data efficiently and effectively is becoming increasingly critical. Statistical machine learning tools have been proven to be very effective in solving many such problems. The goal of this short course is to provide a comprehensive overview of statistical machine learning methods and some recent research developments in machine learning.

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Topics include basics of statistical learning, classical methods as well as modern techniques including sparse shrinkage methods such as LASSO, Support Vector Machines, Boosting, Generalized Additive Models, and more. Various application examples will be discussed as well.

课程编码：011M7025H 英文名称：Nonlinear Combinatorial Optimization 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：堵丁柱

教学目的要求
现代科学技术发展中出现众多非线性组合优化问题，形成组合优化的一个新兴研究方向。多数非线性组合优化问题是NP 难的，人们很难在多项式时间内得到它们的精确解，但是这些非线性组合优化问题的广泛应用又使其求解成为必需。因此，应对之道之一就是牺牲精度换取时间，即在多项式时间内得到问题的一个近似解，这便是近似算法。非线性组合优化问题的近似算法设计与分析有其自身的一些特点，本课程将结合经典的近似算法设计与分析方法，介绍针对非线性组合优化问题的基本算法设计技巧，例如local search 与continuous greedy 等。此外，本课程还将介绍非线性组合优化的一些应用，力求学员能掌握方法的本质并灵活应用于具体问题的解决。

预修课程

教材

主要内容
本门课程主要内容分为两部分。第一部分为submodular maximization；第二部分为nonsubmodular optimization。具体如下：

Part 1. Submodular Maximization
A general model, algorithm and theorem; Influence maximization; Information diffusion models; Kempe-Kleenburg-Tardos conjecture; Randomized approximation.

Part 2. Nonsubmodular Optimization
DS decomposition and BP decomposition; Submodular-supermodular algorithm; Data-dependent approximation; Lovazs Extension and discrete DC function.

本课程主要讲授李代数中的一些内容，包括有限维复半单李代数的结构和表示理论。具体包括Cartan子代数，根系，根空间分解，Dynkin图， Cartan 矩阵，有限维单李代数的分类及有限维复单李代数的有限维表示。 希望通过本课程的学习使学生掌握李代数的基本理论与方法，为进一步获得现代数学知识奠定必要的代数学基础。

自古以来，人类就对自然、世界、宇宙充满好奇。宇宙是什么？生命是什么？万物怎么起源？生命怎么起源？宇宙是怎么发展而来的？将来何去何从？莫大的宇宙与生命间有何深层联系？当今科学究竟对这些根本问题了解了到什么程度？当今最杰出的科学思想家们在想什么？难道他们想的问题是我们普通人无法理解的吗？他们对宇宙世界是怎个看法？他们在争论什么？是“多宇宙”，是“人择”，还是“智慧设计”？物质世界是实在还是虚幻？他们手头有什么过硬的证据来证明自己的观点？科学和宗教谁来拯救谁？本课正是企图对这些极有趣而又扣人心弦的问题和故事做个深入浅出的介绍和探讨，浅到日常之理，深到宇宙至理。通过本课我们可以欣赏到丰富的科学图表和精美科学画面，让我们体会到人类认识自然的艰辛历程，惊叹价值万金的科学数据，享受崇高思想的伟大成就。更重要的是本课可以开阔眼界，打开多学科交叉性思路，想一些高深层次的终极问题，这些问题或许对您终身有用。当然本课不可能解答所有科学难题，它却提供了师生之间各学科同学间的交流平台，供大家相互启发和争辩。好奇，一直是科学进步的强大动力。让您参加到我们的大讨论中来吧！

现代特种加工

课程编码：051M7001H 英文名称：Non-Traditional Machining 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：沈仲鑫

教学目的要求
2018年夏季学期已经是沈仲鑫教授主讲“特种材料加工”的第八年，除了继续讲述“激光材料加工原理”以外，也讲述“离子束，电子束材料加工”，“３Ｄ激光打印”，“等离子体加工”，“金刚石刀具精密加工”，“超精密磨加工”，“电火花加工（EDM，包括线切割），”“电化学加工（包括电解磨）”，还重点讲述“微纳加工（包括光刻）”以及在微电子工业中的应用。

本课程向美国密歇根大学机械工程系2009年开设的“Principles of Laser Materials Processing”课程看齐，我们基本上与他们同步，2011年开设了该课程，到今年已经第八年。同时，我们参考了俄国科学家的工作，讲述了激光材料加工的物理，定性和半定量地介绍了有关参数，将实验与模拟做了比较，达到了较好的效果。今年，“现代特种加工技术”这门课的内容，包含了我们以前开设的课程所覆盖的章节。当前，“激光材料加工”不但是材料加工的一种特殊方法，而且成了一门综合加工技术，“激光3D打印加选择性激光熔融（SLM）”，采用高温预热工艺以防止裂纹的产生，达到了理论密度；并与机械手联合操作，扫描，遥控，检测，数据采集和反馈等自动控制技术综合应用，被汽车工业和精密零部件制造，以及医疗生物等领域广泛采用。其中，尤其是“飞秒光纤激光器”，我们将描述此种激光器的基本原理以及其关键技术，并系统介绍它特有的性质：光斑小，转换效率高，可靠性好，操作成本低，光束质量高，传输灵话，设计简单，系统逻辑, 且大表面散热, 可用风冷等等。另外，我们还讲述：金刚石精密加工，超精密磨加工，电火花加工（EDM），电化学加工（ECM），离子束和电子束等高能束加工，超声波和射流加工，以及MIT的微纳加工等。要求选课的同学能够了解这些技术的前沿，能将它们应用到自己的研发创新工作中去。

大学数学和物理

教材
教材：均来自联合国教科文组织和SPIE.
【1】Photonics. Technical Applications of Light. Inforgraphics. SPIE 2016.
【2】Inspired by Light, Reflections from the International Year of Light 2015, SPIE, and UNESCO 2016.
【3】Celebrating Light, 50 ways light-based Technologies enrich our world,SPIE, and UNESCO 2015.
【4】沈仲鑫，北京爱迪柯森公司网上报告厅已出版的有关讲座录像（2012-2015）。

主要内容
【1】概论（Introduction)。据2017年11月16日中国科学院院士、北京航天控制仪器研究所所长王巍强调的“精密与特种加工技术”的重要性。我们计划在“概论”中讲“德国工匠”精神， 介绍弗劳恩霍夫应用研究促进协会的工作。
【2】金刚石加工，包括金刚石复合片刀具。我们会将烧结样品带到课堂给同学们做演示，传阅并做细节解释。
【3】超精密磨加工。引入并讲解“表面粗造度”的概念。有关磨加工，我们将以蓝宝石衬底的切磨抛为例来讲精密磨加工。
【4】电火花加工（Electrical Discharge Machining, 简称EDM）。
【6】线切割（Wire EDM)。
【7】有关电化学加工（Electrical Chemical Machining, 简称ECM），包括电解磨。
【8】激光技术在“智能手机，3D打印，和精密材料加工”中的应用。Image of smallest structures.Precise laser drilling.Laser cutting. Smartphones thanks to the laser. 3D printing.激光束(LBM)，离子束(IBM)，电子束(EBM)用作为材料加工的刀具各自的优缺点，以及“等离子体加工”等。
【9】有关超声波(Ultrasonic Machining, 简称USM)和射流加工(Abrasive Water-Jet Machining, 简称AWJM)。
【10】微纳加工。介绍麻省理工学院（MIT)的微纳研发工作。

教材

主要内容
你想在较短时间内就适应实验室阶段的学习与工作吗？你是否不想在初入实验室的时候，走弯路浪费时间与精力？《初入实验室的学问与技巧》将介绍在实验室入门时的一些规律和注意事项，帮助你顺利进入实验室开展工作，使你在做学位论文的过程中得到益处。
本课程主要针对实验生物学领域的学生，如果你是理论、计算等专业，包括偏文科的学生，请不要选择这个课程。
研究生从理论学习转入实验室，开始学位论文的“动手”研究工作，是一个必须经历的关键过程。本课程将涉及：1、如何与导师及其实验室成员相处，从而建立相互理解、相互信任、相互协作的关系，即如何适应实验室文化与工作方式的学问；2、进入实验室的进程，包括实验室的生存规则、实验室的日常事务、第一周你应该做什么、必须遵守的科研安全规则等；3、如何建立你自己的实验小环境，包括实验台、你的基本用具及仪器等；4、如何开展你的论文工作，包括参考文献阅读、综合分析、课题的确定、实验计划、结果的解析等；5、实验记录的标准化，包括类型与格式、内容与维护、准则与诚实等；6、如何陈述你的结果与数据，包括交流技巧、口头陈述、书写学位论文的基本原则等。

主要内容
The objective of the course, as implied by the course content below, is to introduce acquire in-depth knowledge about nanobiotechnology in general, and about its medical applications in particular. Emphasis will be on the applications of nanotechnology in measurements and biosensors, therapy and diagnosis, surface bio functionalization, biocomponent assembly, drug design and drug deliveries, BioMEMS/NEMS, nanotoxicity, tissue engineering, medical imaging, entrepreneurship and environmental health. 课程编码：071M7016H 英文名称：Solid Earth Science 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：Makoto Ueshima等

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
This course is divided into 2 parts:.

In part 1, we introduce some basic knowledge on the state & properties of subduction zones. Most of geological/tectonic processes occur along the plate boundary. We start with understanding that the plate movement is motivated by the release of earth’s internal heat energy. We then attempt to understand the state and properties of subduction zones (e.g. thermal hydrological and geomechanical features) that have been revealed through seafloor and borehole observations. The mechanism of subduction zone earthquakes will be shown as a strain release process along the plate convergent boundary.
This course targets graduate students (master-course level) who has a basic skill on geophysics. Knowledge on differential equations is preferred but not mandatory.

In part 2, we introduce prospecting methods of the electrical conductivity and several topics on electromagnetic methods to monitor crustal activities.
Electrical conductivity is one of the most important physical parameters, and is sensitive to temperature, existence of interstitial fluids such as water and melt, and chemical composition. I begin with introduction of basic characteristics of the electrical conductivity and discuss its importance on elucidating mechanism of crustal activities. Then I introduce fundamentals of the major methods to estimate subsurface electrical conductivity structure; magnetotelluric (MT) method. Since the MT method has become a powerful tool to estimate deeper structure, I introduce several topics on it, covering data acquisition, data processing, forward and inverse problems, and its application in the field, which includes our experiment in the NE part of China.
By monitoring fluctuations of electromagnetic field, we can estimate fluid motion (by electrokinetic phenomenon), variation of stress field (by piezomagnetic effect), variation of subsurface temperature field (by thermal magnetic effect), and so on. By monitoring temporal variation of the electrical conductivity structure, we can know temporal variation of the physical state of the subsurface rocks. Thus, as the last part of this course, I introduce several topics on electromagnetic monitoring to elucidate geophysical mechanisms of crustal activities such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.



Contents

Part 1: State & properties of subduction zones (8 hours)
By Dr. Masa Kinoshita
1 Introduction to active plate-margin tectonics
2 Overview of trench-arc-backarc systems
3 Seafloor and sub-seafloor observations
4 Thermo-hydrogeological structure at plate boundaries
5 State of subduction zones (pressure/temperature/stress/fluid)
6 Subduction zone megathrust earthquakes and tsunamis
7 Phenomena specific to active margins (hydrate, mud diapir, etc.)
8 Exam & Wrap-up

Part 2: Solid Earth Electromagnetism
By Dr. Makoto Uyeshima (12 hours)

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Fundamental components of inverse theory in seismology concern (i) spectral perturbation, (ii) linearized
transmission tomography, and (iii) inverse (single) scattering – tied to reflection tomography. An asymptotic
description of (ii) leads to the geodesic X-ray transform, while an asymptotic description of (iii) leads to
the generalized Radon transform. Surface-wave tomography can be asymptotically described as a coupled
tomography and spectral inverse problem.
The goal of this course is to provide an overview of approaches and techniques to imaging the materials
properties and processes in the earth primarily under (ii) and (iii). We focus on developments in reversetime migration (RTM) including the notion of array receiver functions, extended imaging, a variational
formulation for “full waveform inversion” and wave-equation tomography. We discuss data processing and
applications pertaining to the crust and the mantle. The course will consist of 16 hours of lectures and a
written exam (2 hours).
http://maartendehoop.rice.edu/ten-topics-in-seismic-imaging
PART 1 [4 hours]: ray-wave duality
• wave equation, asymptotics
– plane waves, oscillatory integral representations
– method of stationary phase
– geometrical optics, rays
• elastic body waves, anisotropy, polarizations (qP, qSV, qSH)
• elastic surface waves
PART 2 [5 hours]: common source (event), RTM
• reverse-time migration (RTM) and inverse scattering: scalar waves
– reverse-time continued fields
– resolution, illumination analysis
• reverse-time migration (RTM) and inverse scattering: elastic waves, radiation patterns
PART 3 [2 hours]: applications
• array receiver functions
• sampling, wavefield reconstruction, curvelets
PART 4 [3 hours]: multi-source techniques
• extended imaging, downward continuation
– caustics and artifacts
• reflection tomography via RTM and extended imaging
PART 5 [2 hours]: towards FWI
• full waveform inversion (FWI), gradient decomposition
• adjoint state method
EXAM [2 hours] (material: PARTS 1-4, OPEN BOOK/PERSONAL NOTES)

教学目的要求
在科学研究中,我们总是会面临两个基本问题: [1] 实验数据中有没有未知的新知识・新现象（如物理的/化学的）；[2]如何作出新的数学理论/方法,或者如何利用现有的数学理论/方法从实验数据中最有效,最可靠,最精确地把有用的信息提取出来.我们的课程将主要集中于第二个问题.随着地空观测技术的巨大进步,现有的数学理论/方法可能已经不能满足我们的需要.另一方面,随着科学技术的发展,我们可能发现某一学科的数学基础理论可能不完美,有缺陷,需要更新.我们本数学地球科学高级强化课程的主要目的就是要学生学习如何利用利用现有的数学理论/方法解决自己的问题,必要时,如何作出新的数学理论/方法去解决自己的问题.

对于一个科学或者工程问题,我们都必须直接面对如下几个问题:[1]模型恰不恰当? 模型还需不需要改进? 模型/数据组合是否匹配? [2]实验观测数据是否有异常值?如果实验观测数据包含异常值怎么办? 怎么才能保证实验结果不受异常值的影响? [3]现实的科学或者工程问题一般都是非线性的,可能有多个局部最优解,怎么才能保证得到正确的全部最优解? [4]一般说来,我们不能对我们感兴趣的量/信息进行直接量测或者直接观测,而只能通过间接观测求解.这样的问题经常是不适定问题,就是说,其解可能不存在,不唯一,或者不稳定.对于这样的问题,我们怎么才能从实验观测数据最有效,最可靠,最精确地得到我们感兴趣的量/信息? [5]在地球科学或者其它科学/工程问题中,我们可能需要利用不同类型的数据进行求解,怎么才能对各种不同实验观测数据进行同化或者联合处理?

Addressed topics

• how do we evaluate GPS uncertainties ? (difference between formal and a posteriori) can we trust them ?
• difference between precision and accuracy (internal consistency like repeatability is assertion of precision, comparison with other method affected by different biases is accuracy)

4. Rigid plate tectonics: motion and deformation

5. Deformation pattern in elastic medium

• Elastic medium equations
• Vertical fault in elastic medium => arctangent
• General elastic dislocation (Okada’s formulas)

6. The seismic cycle
• Elastic accumulation and rupture on a fault. Example on a Strike-slip fault and a Subduction fault

• Triggering of earthquake

• correlation between co-seismic ruptures and inter-seismic accumulation patterns
• shallow vs deep ruptures. Impact on Tsunami hazard.

课程编码：071M7014H 英文名称：Global Geodynamics 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：CAMBIOTTI GABRIELE

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Global Geodynamics

This course opens up new perspectives on the physics of the Earth’s interior, looking at our planet in an integrated fashion and focusing on the geophysical and geodetic techniques that record, over a broad spectrum of spatial wavelengths, the ongoing modifications in the shape and gravity of the Earth. Basic issues related to the rheological properties of the Earth’s mantle and to its slow deformation will be understood, within the framework of an analytical normal mode theory.

Fundamentals of this theory are developed for self-gravitating compressible Maxwell Earth based on the Preliminary Reference Earth Model and for different forcings, like surface and internal loads, seismic sources and tidal and centrifugal potentials. These forcings allow to simulate deformations caused by present-day and past ice melting, mantle density heterogeneities from mantle convection and earthquakes, as well as to account for the readjustment of the rotational bulge in response to these geophysical processes.

First, we deal with the expansion in spheroidal and toroidal harmonics of the momentum and Poisson equations and, for the linear viscoelastic Maxwell rheology, the Correspondence Principle is considered for obtaining the viscoelastic solution from the equivalent elastic problem. Both normal mode and complex contour integration techniques are used for anti-transforming the field from the Laplace domain to the time domain. Boundary conditions at the surface of the planet, at the core-mantle boundary and at the internal interfaces between layers of different elastic and density characteristics, are obtained. Second, we derive the analytical solutions for two most representative cases of Earth’s models: the stratified viscoelastic incompressible model and the self-compressed viscoelastic compressible sphere. Within the scheme of the Correspondence Principle, these analytical solutions make possible to gain a deep insight into the relaxation spectra of incompressible and compressible Earth’s models, via normal modes or complex contour integration. Love numbers, for surface, unitary, constant loads, are finally explored during their time evolution.

The linearized theory of rotation for viscoelastic planetary bodies, like the Earth, is developed. The MacCullagh’s formula linking the inertia and gravitational perturbations is self-consistently derived within our formalism. The concept of True Polar Wander (TPW) is introduced, and attention is devoted to the physics of viscoelastic, rotational bulge readjustment. Different rotation theories that appeared in the literature are compared, including the effects of non-hydrostatic bulge contribution and compressible versus incompressible rotational bulge readjustment. The long-term behavior of the rotation equation is considered, and a linearized theory for TPW driven by mantle convection is provided.

教学目的要求
第四纪是地球历史中最新的一个阶段，也是人类起源与演化的最重要时期；因此，第四纪生物演化与人类的关系最为密切；此外，更新世动物群还是现生动物的最直接祖先。在过去两百多万年中，地球环境及动物群经历了剧烈变化，了解这些变化规律，对人类应对现今地球环境变化及指导人类的各项实践活动，最终达到持续发展都具有极大参考价值。
选修本课程的学生需要有基本的生物学和/或古生物学及地质学或史前考古学方面知识。通过学习后，希望学生能掌握如下内容：哺乳动物的基本特征、第四纪哺乳动物的分类及演化、主要类群的鉴定特征（重点是骨骼和牙齿特征）、第四纪常见哺乳动物属种及其时空分布规律等。
本课程适合古生物学与地层学、第四纪地质学、进化生物学、史前考古学、动物考古学、古环境学及现代哺乳动物学等相关研究领域的研究生。

教学目的要求
微量元素是指自然界中通常丰度低于1%或0.1%，并用现代分析技术可检测出的所有化学元素。微量元素地球化学是研究自然物质和自然体系中微量元素的分布规律、存在形式、活动特点、控制因素及其地球化学意义的地球化学分支。本课程主要介绍元素分类和不同类型微量元素的特征、分馏和分布规律及其控制因素，包括微量元素地球化学的热力学基础、微量元素的分配系数及其控制因素、微量元素温度计、年代计、岩浆作用中微量元素的行为和微量元素示踪等，使学生初步掌握微量元素地球化学的基本理论和方法，分析流体与岩浆活动过程中微量元素的溶解、沉淀与结晶过程，通过微量元素行为解释岩石和矿床的成因及构造背景等。

构造层次的概念与问题。构造地质学三大难题：低角正断层，高角逆断层与宽V形共轭走滑断层(wide-open V-shaped conjugate strike-slip faults)。变质核杂岩与伸展拆离断层。韧性组构的发育和运动学、动力学含义。挤出构造(extrusion tectonics）与渠流理念（channel flow）。走滑挤压与走滑拉张构造与变（位）形分解作用。构造地质学的新理论—岩石变形的最大有效力矩准则。运动学涡度的理论与实践。造山作用与晚造山伸展垮塌作用。 第1讲：构造地质的历史和现状、基础应变理论回顾。 第2讲：构造层次。 第3讲：应变分解。 第4讲：涡度及其应用。 第5讲：韧性组构的形成、发育。 第6讲：低角度正断层、变质核杂岩及片麻岩穹隆。 第7讲：大型逆冲断层。 第8讲：岩石变形的最大有效力矩准则。

课程编码：072M7009H 英文名称：Global Tectonics 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：TIMOTHY MICHAEL KUSKY等

教学目的要求
从上世纪60年代大陆漂移学说的流行到如今，板块构造理论经过几十年的发展已经演变成地球科学领域的基础思想，一门对地质过程和地质地体演化进行定性分析以及理论检验的地球科学基本理论。板块构造解释了诸如欧亚板块与印度板块碰撞、美洲西缘之下俯冲作用以及大洋中脊扩张等自然现象。板块构造理论不仅可以追溯大陆和海洋在地质历史时期的地理位置和排列组合，还能帮助地学家理解具有板块运动的行星运行机制。该课程将给学生讲解有关板块构造地质学领域的最基本知识、思维方式和研究技能，包括板块运动学及动力学分析、大洋岩石圈和蛇绿岩、俯冲带与加积楔、大陆碰撞早造山带、地幔柱与大火成岩省的一些基础知识部分。总的要求是以认识板块运动学特征为主，理解离散边界、聚合边界和转换边界各地质现象特征为辅。无论哪一部分，均从大地构造演化的总体格局进行理解，强化板块构造意识的培养和板块运动学分析能力的初步训练。

预修课程
普通地质学、地史学、矿物岩石学、构造地质学、地球化学、变质岩石学

教材
Kearey, P., Klepeis, K. A., and Vine, F. J., 2009. Global tectonics 3rd Ed. John Wiley & Sons, Ltd, Publication.

主要内容
板块构造理论是建立在普通地质学、地史学、矿物岩石学、构造地质学和地球化学等课程基础之上的一门综合性学科。通过本课程的学习，为学生深入理解野外构造地质现象、岩石学特征和地球化学特征等相关课程学习和开展相关研究打下基础。
其基本内容主要包括大陆漂移理论和威尔逊旋回、板块运动学特征、板块边界结构特征、大陆裂解、大洋岩石圈及蛇绿岩、俯冲带及加积楔、大陆碰撞及造山带等相关专业知识，以及板块构造理论的应用和初步的野外工作方法等。该课程将阐述岩石圈结构的定量分析，众多扭转刚性板块的分类和相互间的独立运动；检验板块边界的二维或三维几何特征；讨论离散边界、聚合边界和转换边界的几何特征及演化规律；讲解板块变形的地质力学特征和不同类型板块边界的结构；阐述不同大地构造背景下沉积岩盆地的差异和热沉积历史；讲解不同大地构造背景下的区域变质作用等。三联点的稳定性、几何特征和地质效应以及迁移被列入教学内容。同时对大火成岩省、地幔柱以及热点轨迹的性质及起源进行阐述。此外，本课程将阐述板块运动随着时间演化的定性分析和帮助学生理解描述板块运动的各度量单位包括厘米/年、经纬度/时间、旋转角度、年份等。
通过本课程的学习, 要求学生能初步理解板块构造理论，理解离散边界、聚合边界以及转换边界之间的区别以及各自的特征性地质现象。掌握不同大地构造背景的沉积岩盆地特征以及不同大地构造背景下的区域变质作用。同时要求学生能理解大火成岩省、地幔柱以及热点轨迹的性质及起源。
教学基本内容、重点、难点
1 第一章 绪论 介绍大地构造理论的基本概念、内容、意义和历史演变。
2 第二章 板块边界结构特征 重点介绍三大板块边界离散边界、聚合边界以及转换边界的结构构造特征、各自的特征性地质现象和相互间区别。
3 第三章 大陆漂移理论和历史演变 从大陆漂移理论的提出到大陆漂移的直接证据，从大洋盆地特征、大洋地壳组成、洋底扩张、地球磁场转换和板块运动驱动力等方面介绍板块构造理论的起源和发展。
3 第四章 威尔逊循环 从大陆裂解、洋盆形成、转换断层、大洋俯冲作用以及陆陆碰撞等方面阐述威尔逊循环。
4 第五章 大陆裂解 阐述大陆裂解的形成原因、地质特征、区域构造地质特征、裂解火成岩特征和相关地质现象，并列举现存大陆裂解实例，增强学生了解。
5 第六章 地幔柱 阐述地幔柱形成机制、地质特征、区域构造地质特征、地幔柱相关岩浆作用特征等，阐述大火成岩省的形成机制及地质研究意义。
6-7 第七章 洋底扩张和转换断层 从洋底扩张速率、洋底地质特征、洋壳组成、大洋中脊特征、热点轨迹等方面阐述洋底扩张；从地球旋转、旋转欧拉极、大陆边缘走滑断层和盆地等方面阐述转换特征相关特征。教学难点：对转换断层和旋转欧拉极的理解。
8-9 第八章 板块运动学 从地幔对流、洋脊扩张和俯冲板片等三大驱动力阐述板块运动机制，详细描述板块动力学基本要素：板块边界、三联点、板块绝对运动和相对运动、旋转欧拉极等。并列举二维和三维地质实例进行详细说明和解释。教学难点：运动物理学知识解译板块间的相对运动和绝对运动，以及利用极射赤平投影图来板块相对运动方向等。
9 第九章 大洋岩石圈的形成 从地幔减压熔融、洋底地质构造特征、洋壳组成和沉积特征以及大洋岩石圈地震剖面等方面阐述大洋岩石圈的形成作用。
10-11 第十章 蛇绿岩 详细阐述蛇绿岩的基本概念、从下到上的岩石单元组成、形成过程、不同的大地构造形成背景和地质研究意义、以及蛇绿岩全球分布特征。会涉及到蛇绿岩概念的起源、时变和革新。教学难点：理解如何在野外辨别蛇绿岩以及蛇绿岩的大地构造形成背景。
12-13 第十一章 俯冲带 详细阐述俯冲作用形成机制，洋洋俯冲和洋陆俯冲的差异，俯冲作用相关的深成地震和火山作用形成机制、条件以及各自特征，俯冲带的构造地质特征、岩石地球化学特征和地质研究意义等。教学重点。
14-15 第十二章 增生楔 从洋底扩张、洋片俯冲、海沟沉积、加积楔、弧前盆地、岛弧火山作用、被动大陆边缘和稳定大陆块等横向地质分布特征阐述增生楔的形成机制、构造地质特征和岩石组合特征以及变质特征，并介绍构造混杂岩的概念和地质意义。列举大量世界范围内不同类型的增生楔特征便于学生理解。难点在于理解增生楔内复杂的构造地质特征和各种类型的岩石组合特征。教学重点。
16 第十三章 聚合边界盆地 阐述与俯冲作用相关的海沟盆地、弧前盆地、弧后盆地和前陆盆地以及与碰撞作用相关的前陆盆地和拉伸盆地，包括它们的地质构造特征、沉积作用、沉积物特征和地质研究意义。
17-18 第十四章 大陆碰撞 详细阐述大陆碰撞造山带的造山作用、地质构造特征、岩浆作用特征、变质作用特征和碰撞造山后拉伸作用等。教学重点。
19 第十五章 地球整体运动学 从外在因素如地球自转和万有引力，内部因素如地幔柱和地幔对流、洋底扩张、转换断层和俯冲碰撞作用，并结合全球范围内的研究实例对地球整体运动学进行详细阐述。
20 第十六章 板块构造随时间的演化 板块构造的起源一直存在争议。此章将从中太古代（38亿年）到现今的大洋扩张、俯冲和加积的研究实例阐述地质历史时期以来增生造山带内大洋板块地层的地质构造特征、岩石组合特征以及演化特征，并结合前寒武特别是太古代蛇绿岩的鉴定等方面探讨板块构造的起源时间和阐述板块构造随时间的演化等。

教学手段与方法：
该课程由两部分组成。第一部分为课堂教学，采用多媒体与板书相结合授课。第二部分为实验教学，来锻炼学生们的三维板块运动学分析能力。实验教学将在教室利用基本法则和手动绘图完成。该课程采用英语教学为主，中文解释和拓展、延伸为辅的教学方式。

考核方式：
考核以大开卷（实验作业+课程读书报告）的形式进行。要求必须由学生自己组织语言绘图和书写，而不是摘自网络或文献。

1 主要研究方向和主要成就包括：
大气阻塞和北大洋涛动对北半球极端气候事件的发生有重要的调控作用，是国际大气科学研究的难点问题。罗德海教授长期从事大气阻塞和北大洋涛动的动力学研究。在国际上首先提出了阻塞形成的行星尺度波与天气尺度波相互作用的新理论，这是国际上第一次从理论上得到了阻塞的生命过程，并从理论上得到阻塞，天气波和基本西风变化的解析解。系列论文发表在美国大气科学<>杂志上(JAS, Luo 2005a-d, 2006)。之后他又将该理论模型进行了推广，建立了北大西洋涛动(NAO)产生的新的理论模型，这个理论模式不仅能描述NAO活动中心的东移，西风急流的南北变化等问题，而且能解释NAO变化几乎所有的特征。系列论文发表在<>杂志上(JAS, 2007a-c, 2008a-b, 2010a-c,2011, 2012a-b).

课程编码：07MGX014H 英文名称：Life in the Universe: An Introduction to Astrobiology 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：李一良

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Are we alone? Is our Earth, the tiny blue star in this infinite Universe the only harbor for life? This oldest philosophical question frequently appears in scientific fictions and now becomes a science. Astrobiology concerns the study of the origin, evolution and destiny of life in the Universe. The emergence of this science is the natural outcome of the great advances in astronomy, biology and geology. The development of molecular biology has revealed the unitary origin and DNA-coding of all life on Earth, despite the great diversity after a long Darwinian evolution. Geologists dated the origin of life back to almost 3.8 billion years ago. Planetary explorations in our solar system have indicated abundant life materials being stored in the planetesimal zone and beyond. Furthermore, the detection of exoplanets has practically extended life exploration to the deep Universe. The astrobiological studies can be classified into cosmic, planetary, ecosystematic scales on a space dimension and, stellar and interstellar evolution, chemical evolution of prelife on Earth and modern ecosystem on a time dimension. Stellar nucleosynthesis and the evolution of galactic chemistry tell us about the formation of life-essential elements such as H, C-O-N-S-P and Fe-peaked transition metals. So, believe it or not, the elements in our body are much older than Earth! The breakthrough in exoplanet detection is a great step in searching a second life and scientists began to develop techniques to examine the atmosphere composition of Earth-like exoplanets. Based on our understanding of life origin on Earth, a body of liquid water, enough carbon and a silicate crust on a planet with a right distance to its sun are enough premises to make a planet habitable. When those conditions are met, life may start in hundred million years or even shorter time. We understand now that life deeply changes the surface spheres of Earth and our current atmosphere is pretty much the result of biological respiration. We also wonder that the great events happened on Earth, such as the appearance of free oxygen, the starting of plate tectonics, the appearance of ice ages, planet-wide formation of banded iron may have either stimulated the evolution of life, or on the contrary, resulted in mass extinction. Now we are on a fast lane going forward but have a quite unpredictable future. How long can our Gaia last? Can our offspring find another oasis in the Universe? Astrobiology cannot answer these questions but will give you a way to think about them.

Questions
1. Is the appearance of life the inevitable result of universe evolution?
2. Are we the purpose of evolution?

Teaching and Learning Plan
Teaching is made of 7 3-hour lectures. Students will read 10 related articles and write one course essay.

Teaching Language and Method
Teaching language and all learning materials: English.
Suggested Reading Materials (will be provided by the teacher):
From fossils to astrobiology [electronic resource] : records of life on Earth and the search for extraterrestrial biosignatures / edited by Joseph Seckbach and Maud Walsh.
Dordrecht ; London : Springer, 2009.
Complete course in astrobiology [electronic resource] / edited by Gerda Horneck and Petra Rettberg.
Weinheim : Wiley-VCH, c2007.
Lectures in astrobiology [electronic resource] / Muriel Gargaud ... [et al.] (eds.) ; with a preface by Christian de Duve.
Berlin ; New York : Springer, c2005-<2007>
An Introduction to Astrobiology, Gilmour and Sephton, 2004


Abstracts for Topics

From Big Bang to the molecules of life: Evolution of the universe predates both the chemical evolution and the evolution of life. We summarise the origin of the critical elements for life, the CHNOPS, and the initial formation of molecules. From cosmological models we can un-derstand the origin of hydrogen and helium. Later hydrogen will be required when water is formed. Helium, which appears quite useless for life, turns out to be a critical factor in the synthesis of carbon leading to heavier elements. The second compound of water, oxygen, is formed in the hot cores of stars. Once these elements are blown into the cool interstellar space they begin forming interstellar clouds, where a vast spectrum of molecules is formed. The ob-served properties of these molecules, and the larger dust particles will be reviewed. These play an important role in the formation of planets in the accretion disks of a metal rich population of stars. This material reprocessed by the newly formed star and other planets “rains” on the young planet in the form of meteorites, comets and asteroids creating a supply of raw materi-als needed for the prebiotic evolution and the eventual biological evolution of life.

Questions
1. How old is every part of your body?
2. How to understand you are part of the cosmic evolution?
3. What’s the chronology of the appearance/evolution of every part of your body? For exam-ple, the appearance of elements, cells, biofunctions, organs etc.

Building a Planet: The most natural environment for the existence of life and its development is a planet orbiting a star. The planet Earth is the only one as we know it, circling around the Sun with life on it. There are quite a few conditions which need to be satisfied for life to emerge on our planet. This talk focuses on the more basic question of how planetary systems form and evolve. We adopt a methodology which proves itself to be powerful and successful in the field of stellar evolution, which means, we make use of the fact that there are many stars with their planetary systems in the sky in different stages of their evolution. By observ-ing them and building models we can reconstruct the time sequence and find out the most plausible scenarios for planet formation. There are more than 200 mature fully developed plan-etary systems detected and numerous examples of protoplanetary discs, which are believed to be the sites where planets are born. The life history of our planetary system is concisely re-viewed. We will go over how our Solar System was born, starting from the molecular cloud collapse, after passing through a deeply embedded protostellar phase and successively through a T Tauri phase. Next, we will watch how planetesimals and protoplanets form in protoplane-tary discs via sedimentation and agglomeration until the final system arises after 4.6 mld years of its evolution. The Hubble Space Telescope, the Spitzer Space Telescope, the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope, among other missions and instruments, helped us to put together the dif-ferent stages of this scenario. At the end of this lecture we consider briefly also what will happen with a planetary system, like our own, during further evolution of the central star, when the star enters a Red Giant phase and finally become a white dwarf.

Questions:
1. How do you understand the first life is hyperthermophile?
2. How long you think it has taken to cook the first cell?

Prebiotic Chemistry: Before life could arise on a planet, atoms have to organise themselves into complex biological molecules such as proteins, RNA, or DNA. Such elaborated structures can’t appear by themselves at once, they result from a complex chemical evolution, starting with the simplest organic compounds. At some point, at some not-yet-defined stage of com-plexity and organisation of matter, an important step is made and chemistry turns into biology.

This lecture is devoted to the study of prebiotic chemistry; it focuses on the very first steps of the chemical evolution: the synthesis of the building blocks of the molecular engine of any known living organism on Earth. In a previous lecture of this series, how atoms form in stars was explained. Now we consider how atoms can spontaneously combine to make molecules, before discussing the molecular evolution to cellular life in the next lecture.

In the first part of this lecture living systems are dismantled into more elemental fragments: organic molecules. To address the origin of life, the next question would be how those frag-ments can be synthesized in an abiotic manner. After a short historical review about the chem-istry of life different tracks are explored: an endogenous production of the molecules of life, within the Earth atmosphere or in the depths of primitive oceans, or an exogenous source of prebiotic molecules through space delivery via meteorites and comets. The chemical pathways of synthesis of the building blocks of life will then be described.

Questions
1. DNA first or metabolism first?
2. Describe the history of a C atom, from its synthesis in a star to its incorporation into a liv-ing system on an imaginary planet harbouring life.
3. Describe the extent to which RNA molecules could be considered living systems.

From Molecular Evolution to Cellular Life: First, the essential features of cellular life will be considered; what is required for life, and what are the criteria of life. Nucleic acids, genetic code and its expression system are conserved and ubiquitous properties of all life forms, and therefore are assumed to be the most original functional units of life. Molecular analysis of these structures gives suggestions of how they may have been involved in the early molecular evolution, and what functions they may have provided to the early (precellular) replicators. By going backwards, step by step, one sees which inventions had to precede each stage of early evolution: genetically encoded proteins had to exist prior to the establishment of the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA), and RNA-mediated RNA-replication, or so called RNA world, had to predate genetically encoded proteins. Some cellular RNA-molecules, which have different enzymatic activities and are highly conserved between different organ-isms are supposed to be relicts from this era. Still, many questions related to the early molecu-lar evolution remain open. We do not know, for instance, the prebiotic synthesis routes for the nucleotides, how life chose to use the distinct nucleotides and amino acids in their distinct chiralic forms, how the first functional polynucleotides were assembled, or how the earliest life forms were confined.

Questions
1. What are the difficulties in understanding of the origin of life?
2. What are the building blocks of life and how do they assemble to make functional cells?
3. What are the putative steps required for the establishment of self-sustainable life?
4. What kind of conditions might have driven the prebiotic molecular evolution towards life?
5. How do you define the beginning of life?

Mineral-Organic Molecule Interactions: Prebiotic chemistry plays a central role in the inves-tigation of the possible scenarios of the early chemical environments. Its goal is to shed light on the events involved in the synthesis of initial biomolecules and on the self-organization processes that led the last common ancestor. Even though a well defined scenario for the physico-chemical conditions on the primitive Earth is not available, one can assume that a syn-thetic pathway, in order to be considered prebiotic, should use the simplest chemicals and the most common conditions present at that time. Low molecular weight molecules such as carbon dioxide, hydrogen cyanide, formamide and formaldehyde, easily formed from the primitive atmosphere by ultraviolet light, heat or electric discharge as energy sources, have been consid-ered as prebiotic precursors. The catalysis played a crucial role in the prebiotic synthesis of biomolecules starting from these chemical precursors. Several minerals and metal oxides char-acterized by chemical, redox and photochemical catalytic properties were widely diffused on the primitive Earth. These compounds, when components of a reaction mixture, could have enhanced the efficacy of prebiotic syntheses, affecting the selectivities of the reactions and furnishing local microenvironments able either to concentrate dilute reagents or to preserve newly formed biomolecules from degradative processes. In this lecture we will focus on the main concepts of catalysis applied to prebiotic chemistry, including homogeneous and hetero-geneous catalysis, multifunctional catalysis and autocatalysis. Different examples on the role of catalysis in the synthesis of biomolecules starting from simple precursors will be discussed with a special attention to the synthesis of sugars, peptides and oligonucleotides. Examples of prebiotic synthesis of biomolecules with non terrestrial minerals as well as multi-components catalysis will be also described.

Questions
1. What’s your understanding of “clay gene? Do you believe that the mineral surface have catalyzed the syntheses of prebiotic molecules?
2. What’s the role of silicates for a habitable planet?

The Ancestors of Protein: In searching the origin of life it is possible to apply two different approaches. The first one is a down-to-top approach, in which, starting from inanimated mat-ter, like for instance basic organic compounds or amino acids, one tries to reproduce the pro-cesses and the conditions that gave birth to the first living beings about 3.85 Ga ago. Alterna-tively, one may attempt to extract hints about the first steps of the evolution of life from the observation of present organisms. This top-down approach is based on the fact that all living forms have a common ancestor, so that it is licit to assume that some of its vestiges are still preserved inside the genetic code of current cells and bacteria. Indeed, it is well known that there are structures inside proteins, like structural motifs and folds, which seem to be intimate-ly connected with evolution. For example, while there are about 100,000 expressed proteins in eukaryotic systems, there are much fewer motifs and folds, a fact that is related to the path-ways of evolution. In this lecture some aspects of the top-down approach will be illustrated. After a brief review of the known structures in proteins and other macromolecules which are relevant for life, a discussion will follow about the physical and chemical properties of biopol-ymers. Physical and chemical laws were in fact present during the period in which life started on the Earth and have certainly put constraints on the formation of the earliest biopolymers. Therefore, they can be exploited in order to guess how the genome of the most primitive or-ganisms looked like. The information about the general characteristics of ancient life forms obtained using physical and chemical arguments may be used in the search of the remnants of the first genes which could be inside modern genes for instance due to processes of gene fu-sion. The lecture will end up with a discussion about the physical experimental methods that allow the detection of possible substructures inside biopolymers like proteins or DNA.

Extremophiles: Extreme environments are characterized by physical and chemical parameters which were considered lying outside the range which is suitable for life. In recent years, the notion of what constitutes life-limiting conditions in an environment has undergone dramatic changes: microorganisms and occasionally higher organisms were discovered, which not only tolerate, but thrive under ranges of temperatures, pH values, pressures, salinity, ionizing radia-tion etc. previously thought to destruct biomolecules and organisms. Some of the mechanisms responsible for these life styles are in the process of being elucidated. The presence of liquid water is a prerequisite for growth under all kinds of conditions; however, survival of resting stages, such as spores or dormant forms, was shown to occur in vacuum and in space condi-tions for several months. The detection of numerous viable prokaryotes and spores in subterra-nean locations, such as basalt, granite, ancient halite and sediments, suggests the possibility of extensive longevity, perhaps over millions of years.

The implications of these discoveries for the search for extraterrestrial life are severalfold: the probability of finding prokaryotic life in environments such as the subsurface of Mars or the salty ocean of the Jovian moon Europa appears greatly enhanced, and the potential for Panspermia is considered more plausible than ever before.

2. Hypothesis: Mars is already contaminated with terrestrial microorganisms and there is no chance of detecting potential Martian forms of life. Would you agree or disagree?
3. Which molecular mechanisms enable microbial life at extreme temperatures?

Habitability: What do we mean by habitability? Habitability depends on life considered and should be defined by the chemical and physical tolerances for a given organism. As we cur-rently have no direct evidence for life on another planet, habitability is necessarily constrained by our knowledge of life on Earth. We use our knowledge of the extremes of life on Earth to assess extraterrestrial environments and the plausibility that they can support life. I will dis-cuss the use and limitations of the concept of “habitability” and provide examples of how we assess the habitability of other worlds using organisms from extreme environments on Earth. I will discuss how considerations of energy availability (redox couples), the presence of water and carbon sources have shaped our view of the habitability of other planets and will eventu-ally be used to assess the habitability of exoplanets. The formulation of a definition of “habit-ability” can greater assist us in defining the possibilities for life elsewhere.

Questions
1. Describe two factors that might be important for the habitability of a planet. Why are they important?
2. Why is Jupiter’s moon Europa such a focus for astrobiologists? What factors about this moon make it biologically interesting?
3. Describe how the carbonate-silicate cycle is involved in regulating planetary temperature.

Moons of Giant Planets: The data returned by the Galileo spacecraft strongly suggest that a liquid water layer, several tens of kilometers in depth existing beneath the cold icy surface of Jupiter’s moon Europa. This internal ocean would be in contact with the inner silicate core, possibly volcanically active. Interestingly, the (P,T) conditions at the silicate-ocean boundary are quite similar to those existing on the Earth’s sea floor where organisms live without solar energy. The study of Europa is therefore essential to answer such as: does life exist every-where water is present? Can life arise and develop in an environment where there is no sun light? What source of energy may be used by the microorganisms?

The existence of an internal ocean is surprising since the satellite was expected to be frozen due to its very cold surface temperature (~100 K). For several years, tidal dissipation has been invoked to explain the possible presence of an ocean within Europa. Tidal dissipation comes from the viscoelastic response of the satellite to the 3.55-days tidal forcing. In the Laplace resonance, Io and Ganymede force the eccentricity of Europa. As it travels around Jupiter on an eccentric orbit, Europa is subjected to a periodical deformation. Due to the viscoelastic properties of its materials, viscous dissipation by shear friction occurs within each internal lay-er. Tidal dissipation in the inner core may heat up the outer silicate layer resulting in volcanism similar to the one observed on Io. Thermal evolution models indicate that the silicate core could have reached a highly dissipative state only if Europa experienced larger tidal forcing in the past. Future exploration of Europa is required to determine the exact depth of the liquid layer and to assess the possibility of seafloor silicate volcanism.

The lecture reviews our present knowledge on Europa: its geology and its internal structure. Models of tidal dissipation and thermal evolution and their implications for the development of biogenic activity are presented. Concepts for future exploration missions toward Europa are summarized, with particular emphasis on the search for liquid water and on the exobiological potential of that ”ocean” satellite.

Titan: Titan, largest satellite of Saturn, with a diameter of 5150 km, is the only satellite in the Solar System having a dense atmosphere. Since the discovery of the properties of this atmos-phere, especially its main molecular composition – dinitrogen (N2) with a few percents of me-thane (CH4) – by the Voyager spacecraft observation in the early 80ties, Titan is considered as one of the most interesting bodies of the Solar System with regard to astrobiology. Indeed such an atmosphere is very favorable to the production of organic compounds as demonstrat-ed by the Miller’s now historical experiment and the many similar experiments which were done later on. The likely presence of a complex organic chemistry in Titan’s atmosphere was also directly supported by the detection of many organic compounds detected by Voyager, and by several observations of Titan’s atmosphere from ground-based and Earth orbit tele-scopes. These discoveries were one of the main motivations of the scientific community for going back to the Saturn system with a very ambitious planetary mission: Cassini-Huygens. Most of our current knowledge of Titan is based on the new and very fresh observations done by Cassini-Huygens, coupled to laboratory experiments, including simulation experiments, and theoretical modelling (in particular photochemical models and ionospheric chemical models of the atmosphere, and models of the internal structure of the satellite). The lecture presents some historical data on Titan before Cassini-Huygens, before describing the Cassini-Huygens mis-sion and its scientific payload. Then the models of formation and of internal structure of Titan are summarized and the general astrobiology of Titan is presented. Each of the three main as-trobiological aspects - similarities with the Earth, organic chemistry and habitability – are de-scribed. Among the several fully unexpected discoveries done by the Cassini-Huygens mission are the observations of important geological activities on Enceladus, a smaller satellite of Sat-urn, with a radius of only 250 km. These observations and their potential astrobiological input are briefly described. New concepts for future exploration missions of Titan and Enceladus are presented as a conclusion.
Questions
1. Suppose Titan has an ocean of 100 km in depth, and Earth has an ocean of 4000 m in depth. Calculate the volumes of water on Titan and Earth. Which of them has more water?

Planetary Protection: ESA’s space exploration programme Aurora aims at the robotic and human exploration of the solar system with Mars, the Moon, Europa and the asteroids as the most likely targets. Mars is selected as the destination of the first Aurora Flagship mission ExoMars, followed by a Mars Sample Return mission. The scientific objectives of the Exo-Mars mission are the search for past and present life on Mars, the identification and character-ization of possible hazards to future human exploration and the enhancement of our knowledge about the Martian environment in general. The reach these ambitious goals the im-portance of planetary protection measures becomes obvious. Planetary protection is the term that describes the aim of protecting solar system bodies (i.e. planets, moons, comets, and as-teroids) from contamination by terrestrial life, and retroactive protecting Earth from possible life forms that may be returned from other solar system bodies. Planetary protection is neces-sary (i) to maintain the possibility to study these other solar system bodies in their pristine states, (ii) to avoid terrestrial contamination that would obscure the possibility to find indige-nous life elsewhere and (iii) to ensure that the Earth’s biosphere is protected from potential extraterrestrial sources of biological contamination. COSPAR, the Committee of Space Re-search, has formulated a planetary protection policy and defined planetary protection guide-lines based on article IX of the UN Outer Space Treaty from 1967. The planetary protection procedures that have to be applied to a given spacecraft are determined by the type of mission (e.g. flyby, orbiter, lander, rover) and the biological interest posed by the spacecraft’s destina-tion. Landers and rovers destined towards objects of high biological interest must undergo careful cleaning and sterilization. A Mars lander mission is classified as planetary protection category IVb/c with extremely low bioburden limits among other stringent requirements, if the landing is planned in a so called ‘special region’ with the potential for the existence of extant Martian life. All other landers on Mars are classified as category IVa with less stringent, but still technically challenging requirements concerning bioburden limits. In this lecture the plane-tary protection requirements, the bioburden limits and the principle methods and procedures to fulfil these requirements will be discussed in detail.
Questions
1. Do you think we need a plan to monitor the meteorites or any celestial hazards to protect us from extinction?

Exoplanets: Since the mid-90’s the number of detected extrasolar planets around dwarf stars is rapidly increasing. Today, we know that our solar system is only one among many planetary systems of very different nature. Many of their characteristics know up to now came unex-pected, questioned the traditional theories of planet formation. Nevertheless, our view of planetary systems is still very restricted. Mainly large giant planets have been found so far due to detection limits of the methods used. In the near future the already working space mission CoRoT (CNES) and the upcoming mission Kepler (NASA) are expected to find the first Earth-sized, terrestrial planets. Many of these terrestrial planets detected will probably be on short-period orbits or larger than Earth, forming to new classes of potentially habitable planets, so-called “hot-Earth” and “super-Earth”. However, under which conditions terrestrial extraso-lar planets are providing habitable conditions still remains to be investigated. Habitability de-pends e.g. on the atmospheric composition and climate. Atmospheric models are used to pre-dict the climatic conditions on different types of terrestrial planets and to predict the spectro-scopic signatures of a potential biosphere. Such biospheric signals can be investigated by planned space missions like Darwin (ESA). The lecture will present the methods to detect ex-trasolar planets, the main characteristics of the planets found so far and the expectations we have concerning habitable planets and the potential to detect biosignals in their atmosphere.

Questions:
1. Use your imagination to draw a picture of a living world somewhere in the deep universe. Discussion on extraterrestrial civilization is also welcome.
2. If there is a habitable planet in the deep space, please give the similarities and differences you can image between it and Earth.

Cosmic Dusts: Analysing extraterrestrial dust samples, i.e. Interplanetary Dust Particles (IDPs) and cometary dust collected in situ (Stardust samples), is critical to understand the role played by dust grains in driving the formation of complex molecular compounds relevant for the prebiotic chemistry occurred in the early Earth. In particular, one of the driving forces for cometary dust study is looking for confirmation of the historical theory, hypothesized by Hal-ley, published by Newton in his Principia in 1686, and developed more or less continuously ever since that comets may have played an important role for the development of life on Earth. The extent to which comets enriched the primordial Earth with reactive C-bearing molecules and water is not known. The estimate of the endogenous contribution to Earth’s organic in-ventory during this period is in the order of 108-1010 kg year-1, while the flux of organic matter delivered to the Earth via comets and asteroids, averaged over the heavy bombardment period, may have been even larger at around 1011 kg year-1.

Organic molecules have been detected in comets by comet fly-bys and by astronomical ob-servations. The presence of C-bearing molecules in comets is to be expected based on numer-ous astronomical observations in which complex organic molecules have been detected, in dense molecular clouds and the diffuse interstellar medium. Dense clouds are known to con-tain mixed molecular ices. The radiation processing of these ices could produce a host of or-ganic species, including some of astrobiological interest. Molecular clouds are the parent reser-voirs of protoplanetary disks, like the solar nebula, where grains were further irradiated and the effects of which may be at least as important as those occurring in the diffuse Interstellar Medium (ISM). Organic molecules in comets could show a higher complexity than the dif-fuse ISM due to the reaction with fine grains of variable compositions such as ices and sili-cates as well as carbon grains and various molecules. Silicates act as catalysts for the reaction of organic molecules to higher complexity. The catalytic effects of cosmic dust analogues in prebiotic reactions have been studied in the laboratory at high temperatures and in conditions simulating the environments assumed for the early Earth. A large suite of complex organic molecules have been synthesized in the gas phase on the surface of cosmic silicate dust ana-logues.

We will illustrate the methods of analysis and recent results obtained on cometary grains. The laboratory techniques that identify the C-rich entities present in the dust grains, provide in-formation on their organic component, morphology, mineralogy and chemical composition. In particular, micro-Raman and micro-infrared spectroscopy, Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy and Energy Dispersive X-ray analyses have been applied on grains extracted from the Stardust aero-gel cometary collector. The results of these analyses in terms of the nature of the organic matter present and a comparison of these findings with what is known about or-ganic molecules in the ISM will be discussed.

主要内容
教学内容简介
There seems to be a shift in physical geography from a qualitative perspective to a more quantitative perspective. The increasing availability of vast amount of spatial data and the rapid advancement of GIS/RS and other spatial information processing techniques make this shift more viable. The central idea of this course is to illustrate how modern spatial information processing theory and techniques are used in quantifying the spatial variation of geographic variables in physical geography.

This course focuses the application of GIS, artificial intelligence (A.I.) techniques and fuzzy logic concepts in solving physical geography problems. The discussion will be centered around the problem of detailed inventory of natural resources and natural hazards. The course will first present the need for detailed inventory of natural resources and susceptibility to hazards. It will highlight the challenges facing conventional approaches for conducting this type of inventory. It then presents how modern spatial information processing theory and techniques helps to overcome these challenges. The specific cases used in this course are soil resource inventory, landslide susceptibility and wildlife (monkey) habitats mapping. The techniques to be discussed include: personal construct-based knowledge acquisition, neural networks, case-based reasoning, and spatial data mining, purposive sampling, and VGI-based techniques. Each of the techniques will be introduced and discussed using a real application. Software and real world data set will be provided.

教学目的要求

高性能运算与应用

课程编码：091M7002H 英文名称：High Performance Computing and Applications 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：HAIXIANG LIN

教学目的要求
Objectives:
The course provides an introduction to the architectures of parallel computers, exiting parallel programming languages and tools, and basic principles in designing parallel algorithms. Efficient algorithms play a crucial role in achieving high performance, so a large part of the course discusses the hierarchical methods. As communication becomes increasingly the dominant overhead in large parallel systems, we will review techniques of reducing communication in numerical algorithms, for example,asynchronous optimization algorithms for machine learning.

预修课程

教材
教材：
1. 课程网站上的课件和阅读资料。
2. H.X. Lin, Parallel Computing, Lectures Notes, Delft University of Technology, 2008.
3. C. Oosterlee, H.X. Lin, P. Wesseling, et al., Computational Science and Engineering, Lectures Notes, Delft University of Technology, 2004.

主要内容
Content:
1. Introduction
History of high performance computing，demands from computational science and engineering for more computing power, challenges in hardware, algorithm and software design as computer systems are getting larger and towards petaflop scale.
2. HPC systems
A brief introduction to parallel and distributed system architectures, communication network, memory organization, etc.
3. Design and analysis of parallel algorithms
Basic principles of designing parallel algorithms, data dependency and directed acyclic graphs, load balancing and overhead, performance model, data locality, scalability analysis.
4. Parallel programming
Introduction to shared address space versus message-passing model, mechanisms for enforcing data dependences (semaphore or synchronous communication), , OpenMP, CUDA,MPI and hybrid programming.
5. Parallel numerical algorithms
Parallel iterative methods (Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel, SOR and CG), domain decomposition.
6. Hierarchical methods and parallelization
Multi-grid method, N-Body simulation and Big data visualization (Barnes-Hut algorithm and Fast Multipole method)
7. Communication reduction and asynchronous algorithms
Reducing communication overhead becomes an increasingly more important issue as the number of nodes and cores in supercomputer systems increases (to the millions), a number of techniques for reducing communication overhead in parallel numerical algorithms are discussed to meet the future challenge. Asynchronous optimization in machine learning

课程编码：091M7005H 英文名称：Software Engineering Paradigm and Technology in the Era of Big Data 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：HAI KUAN LI

教学目的要求
教学目的:
本课程旨在让学生了解大数据时代软件生产模式的变迁以及在新的软件开发模式下实现软件开发的具体技术及其相关案例，以便在毕业后尽快适应工业化的软件开发环境。

预修课程

教材

主要内容
内容提要:
大数据时代的到来，正日益深刻地改变着传统软件的生产模式。软件开发正迅速趋向数据化、智能化、架构化与集约化。传统的软件生产方式已在瓦解，一个新的软件开发模式正在形成。
首先，软件即数据（SAD）、软件定义一切（SDE）与万物互联（IoE）的概念使我们看到了巨大的软件资源；而软件资源的大规模智能重用必将大大地改变软件生产的面貌；用传统高级程序语言开发软件的时代终将过去；而在架构层基于动态软件资源的动态程序设计技术将得到迅速发展。然而什么是动态软件资源，什么是动态程序设计呢？
本课程将讨论在大数据时代软件开发模式的变化、特征及其发展趋势。除新的概念外，还将重点介绍一些具体的实现方法，技术以及工业实践经验，包括主讲老师在荷兰代尔夫特大学的研究工作以及在国际知名企业的实践案例。
我们正处于一个软件工业大变革的前夜。随着软件需求的迅速增长与软件资源的大量积累与有效利用，软件生产的集约化与自动化程度都将迅速提高，软件生产质量与效率的大幅度改进将成为可能。一个软件智造的时代正在到来，人们的生活方式以及世界的面貌都将发生深刻的变化。

教学目的要求
当前人工智能技术如火如荼，受到了学术界、产业界直至各行各业的广泛关注。图像、视频等多媒体内容的智能分析是人工智能的重要方面，一个典型例子是深度学习技术受到广泛追捧的触发点也是在图像分类技术中的性能提升。本课程拟从多媒体内容的智能分析与应用等方面开展介绍，分析当前学术论文和期刊上的最新代表性工作以及目前产业界的最新技术动态，拟从全局上介绍目前研究现状、典型技术、可能的应用场景及未来的趋势。希望通过此课程，能够让大家了解相关的研究进展和趋势，并对一些具体研究问题有进一步的深入认识。

详细内容:
大数据时代的系统芯片设计

课程编码：091M7008H 英文名称：SoC Design in Big Data Era 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：CHEN CHUN ZHANG

教学目的要求
In today’s big data era, one of the most important impacts is coming from the AI studies. In the AI research, especially in the deep learning area such as the well-known CNN methodology, has resulted in demands on data processing in two-folds, i.e. data modeling and analysis for system-level design, and the data storage and application for various system-on-chip (SoC) designs.

预修课程

教材

主要内容
In this course, the impact of big data on concurrent technology in integrated circuit (IC) field will be first discussed, followed with a review on challenges, methodologies, and/or EDA solutions, of SoC design, integration and implementation.
One of the originated sources of big data generation is the Internet of Things (IoT), where the data are collected, converted via an IoT device to electronic signal, which are analyzed and processed by a SoC assembled on the receiving system. To meet the big data era needs, variety of SoC designs for IoT device and electronic end-products, are emerging and consequently resulted in these topics: 1) the complexity of and challenges in today’s SoC designs; 2) SoC design and implementation; 3) to achieve high performance and low power; 4) to produce high reliable products with high yield.
Throughout the class, the students are expected to learn of the state of the art of SoC design methodology and principles, why and how, with the comprehensive courseware in PPT, and quoted teaching references.

教学目的要求
随着“大数据”时代的来临，数据之间的关联性更加重要，产生了大量的关联数据，例如从海量数据中抽取知识并构建知识图谱，以及社交网络数据等等。例如面向海量知识图谱，如何存储、查询海量知识图谱数据就是一项具有挑战的研究问题；面向海量社交网络等图数据，如何发现有趣的社区，也众多互联网应用中也是一项重要的技术挑战。

详细内容:
压缩感知的进展及其应用

课程编码：101M7012H 英文名称：Developments of Compressed Sensing and Applications 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：李世东

教学目的要求
作为信息和数学结合紧密的新学科，压缩感知（Compressed Sensing/CS）理论和应用的发展举世瞩目。对于稀疏(或者变换后的稀疏)信号，压缩感知理论能把其采样率降低到传统采样率的几分之一，甚至更少。CS的实践也展示了极具诱惑的成效，但理论和实践仍存很大的差距，问题也变得更难。本课程在基本原理简介之后，将首先讨论理论与实践的差距，然后探讨理论和算法的新进展，从传统稀疏信号重建的唯一性原理，推广到欠稀疏信号下重建的唯一性原理，以及欠稀疏信号的重建算法。从而阐述如何把压缩感知的应用推广到更多、更复杂的信号/图像处理的应用中。
课程将列举若干有待解决的理论和实践问题 (open problems) 作为结束前的讨论重点。


压缩感知（Compressed Sensing）理论是近几年发展最快、最新、也是最具生命力的信息和数学结合紧密的新学科。于传统的信息采样的方法截然不同，压缩感知理论能把稀疏信号的采样率降低到传统方法的几分之一，甚至更少。压缩感知的实践展示出其巨大的生命力，但理论和实践仍存很大的距离，仍有巨大的发展空间。了解它的基本原理和理论以及于实践的差距，可望把压缩感知推广应用在更多更复杂的信号/图像处理的应用中。本课程后半部分将阐述压缩感知的基本原理和理论，并结合应用的实例，分析和列举众多有待解决的问题。

课程教师信息

李世东博士的科研方向包括框架和框架的延伸理论及其在信号处理和数据融合中的应用。李教授的博士论文首创了框架多尺度分析理论（Frame Multiresolution Analysis），他亦率先在世界上刻划了框架分解的最一般的形式，并推导了偶框架的一般表达式。李教授还提出并构造了多窗型Gabor分解理论（multi-Gabor expansions）以便多频信号分析的自适应性及改善时频信号分析的分辨率。伪框架理论(Pseudoframes for subspaces) 及其应用也是李教授(与合作者H. Ogawa)创立的新理论。伪框架的提出完全出于实际应用的需求，它的应用已在一些问题中构造出普通框架和基理论所不可能得到的(极有应用价值)解。李教授的较新理论成果是与合作者(P. Cassaza and G. Kutyniok)提出的融合框架理论(Fusion Frames)，以及新近又提出的非正交融合框架理论。 融合框架是数据融合及传感器网络应用中观察和提炼出的理论。它的应用不但可以忠实的刻画一般传感器网络系统，更重要的是可以简化大而难的大网络融合问题。李教授的最新工作是关于信号在框架下稀疏的压缩感知理论和应用。

李教授连续15年主持美国国家自然科学基金科研项目, 也同时持有美国空军研究办公室的关于压缩感知的科研项目。他持有2个专利，另有3项专利在审核中。

教学目的要求
The numerical computation of electromagnetic fields is nowadays an indispensable tool in design, modeling, analysis and diagnoses of electrical and electronic devices in a wide range of industrial sectors. This course offers students an overview of electromagnetic theory, numerical computation methods and industrial applications.

课程编码：102M7012H 英文名称：Basics of Advanced Photonics 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：沈仲鑫

教学目的要求
“高等光子学基础”这门强化课的内容，不但包含了自2011年以来我们开设的“光纤和激光技术导论”所覆盖的层面，论及“飞秒光纤激光器”等，描述这种激光器的基本原理以及其关键技术，并系统介绍它特有的性质：光斑小，转换效率高，可靠性好，操作成本低，光束质量高，传输灵话，设计简单，系统逻辑, 且大表面散热, 可用风冷等等；而且本课程还简要地介绍“光通信的基本原理，光纤传感器网络，wifi和lifi, 光纤放大器（EDFA），无源器件，包括光纤耦合器，隔离器，环路器，波分复用器（WDM），光纤光栅（FBG）和光开关等元器件的结构和应用，以及双包层光纤制备的新工艺”等。要求选课的同学能够了解这些技术的前沿，能将它们应用到自己的研发创新工作中去。

预修课程
大学数学和物理

教材
来自联合国教科文组织和SPIE.
【1】Photonics. Technical Applications of Light. Inforgraphics. SPIE 2016.
【2】Inspired by Light, Reflections from the International Year of Light 2015, SPIE, and UNESCO 2016.
【3】Celebrating Light, 50 ways light-based Technologies enrich our world,SPIE, and UNESCO 2015.
【4】沈仲鑫，北京爱迪柯森公司网上报告厅已出版的有关讲座录像（2012-2015）。

【3】沈仲鑫，北京爱迪柯森公司网上报告厅已出版的有关讲座录像（2012-2015）。

主要内容
第一章基础
I. Basics. Definition of photonics. Smallest points. Highest velocity. Shortest times. Highest power. Undisturbed superposition. Light spectrum. Hidden realm of photonics. Shorter wavelengths. Widow glass vs optical fiber. Mirrors vs laser mirrors. Crystalline supermirrors：from concept to reality.Laser types.Solid state lasers. Semiconductor lasers. Fiber lasers. Disk lasers. Laser vs the Sun. Innovation of laser technologies for 56 years.James Clerk Maxwell: Man of light.
Solar eclipse observations proved that Einstein was right. The French captain’s discovery: Polarized light.

第二章激光技术在“智能手机，3D打印，和精密材料加工”中的应用
II. Production Technology.Image of smallest structures.Precise laser drilling.Laser cutting. Smartphones thanks to the laser. 3D printing.

第三章数据转换，网络，卫星通信，云计算中的光速运作
III.Data Transfer.Optical fiber networks.Laser communication in space. QR-codes.Li-Fi: An anabling technology that can transform our lives.Light in the cloud: photonics innovation for data centers.Light-speed computing.Onboard Lidar detects turbulence, volcanic ash near and far. New frontier for quantum sensing.
光通讯的基本原理，光纤放大器（EDFA），无源器件，包括光纤耦合器，隔离器，环路器，波分复用器（WDM），光纤光栅（FBG），以及双包层光纤制备的新工艺等。

第四章图像获得和显示,以及医疗技术，包括AI.
IV. Image Capture, Display，and Medical Technology.Camera lenses. Gesture control. Flat screen. LCD vs OLED. Counting blood cells. Endoscopy. Seeing near and far. Seeing clearly again.Light-aide: Inspired design opens minds.

第五章照明，交通， 和光伏。
V. Lighting, Traffic, and Photovoltaics.Changing lives with light.White LED light. Brighter with LEDs. Lamp specifications. Intelligent luminaires. Laser shows. Traffic enforcement. Light on and in the car. Car headlights. Airport lighting.Solar cells. Solar energy.

第六章环保,研发和经济
VI. Environmental, Research and Economy. Optical measurements in citizen projects. Forest fire surveillance. Optical sorting. Photonics as an industry sector. Photonics around the globe. Nobel laureates, Photonics countries. Photonics schools. Economic impact of photonics. Photonics enthusiast.

课程教师信息
Dr. Darrin Young received his B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees from the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences at University of California at Berkeley in 1991, 1993, and 1999, respectively. Dr. Young joined the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at Case Western Reserve University in 1999. In 2009 he joined the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at the University of Utah, where he currently serves as an associate chair of the ECE department. Dr. Young’s research interest focuses on developing start-of-the-art MEMS sensors, low-power sensors interface electronics, wireless power transfer, and microsystem integration and packaging technologies for biomedical implantable and wearable monitoring, industrial sensing, and personal navigation application. Dr. Young has published many technical papers in high-impact journals and conferences, and served as a technical program committee member and session chair for a number of reputable international conferences. He also served as an associate editor of the IEEE Journal of Solid-State Circuits, the chair of the IEEE Electron Devices Society-MEMS Committee, and a member of the IEEE Sensors Council. He currently serves as an editor of the IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices.

空间综合电子控制系统

课程编码：101M7002H 英文名称：Space Integrated Electronics and Control Systems 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：董文博

教学目的要求
本课程是为电子电气与通信工程学院开设的专业研讨讲座，主要目的是介绍电子电气技术在空间载荷系统中的应用。
课程内容首先介绍空间电子系统的应用背景和环境特点，然后结合典型的空间综合电子控制系统，介绍各个组成部分的核心原理，包括：空间嵌入式处理器、计算机内部和外部接口、信号检测与数据采集处理、运动部件驱动与控制、电源系统设计、闭环智能控制算法等部分，并介绍了几个典型的空间载荷测控系统、智能控制系统、数据采集管理系统等，介绍空间载荷电子控制工程中的元器件选用、硬件研发、软件工程化、机热设计、可靠性试验，以及工程质量管理等。
课程的最大特色是理论结合实际。课程将以讲师亲历的空间电子控制任务为实例，根据工程实战的研发流程，逐步引出问题和各个知识点，进行强化。逐步串联学生电路、信号、计算机、控制等多门课程，促进形成完整的知识体系，使其融会贯通。并通过实际设计作业，边学边做，培养能力，为成为合格的电子主管设计师做准备。

主要内容
COURSE DESCRIPTION
Machine learning is the study and construction of computer systems that can learn from data without being explicitly programmed. In the past decade, machine learning has given us self-driving cars, practical speech recognition, effective web search, and a vastly improved understanding of the human genome. In this class, you will learn about the most effective machine learning techniques, and gain practice implementing them and getting them to work for yourself. More importantly, you’ll learn about not only the theoretical underpinnings of learning, but also gain the practical know-how needed to quickly and powerfully apply these techniques to solve various business problems based on real-world data, including the dataset from Yelp, Amazon, US Stock Market, etc.

This course provides a broad introduction to machine learning, data mining, and statistical pattern recognition. Topics include: (i) Supervised learning (parametric/non-parametric algorithms, support vector machines, kernels, and neural networks). (ii) Unsupervised learning (clustering, dimensionality reduction, recommendation systems, and deep learning). (iii) Best practices in machine learning.

The major format of this course will be the combination of lecture/case studies/hands-on. Lectures will focus on theory and concepts underlying machine learning; case studies will be used to demonstrate real-world application of these concepts; and hands-on activities will allow the students to implement these solutions using Spark and Octave (a free online version of Matlab).

Major Topics Covered:
1. Introduction to Machine Learning
2. Supervised Learning: Linear Regression and Logistics Regression
3. Supervised Learning: Neural Network
4. Supervised Learning: Classification- Support Vector Machines
5. Unsupervised Learning: Dimensionality Reduction
6. Unsupervised Learning: Anomaly Detection
7. Unsupervised Learning: Recommender Systems
8. Large Scale Machine Learning

Recommended Readings

课程编码：121M7018H 英文名称：Measuring and Increasing Collaborative Innovation 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：Peter Gloor

教学目的要求
This seminar describes how to measure and improve the radical innovation process in organizations:
 How to find innovators, influencers, and trends on online social media
 How to identify cool new ideas using social network analysis
 How to enhance performance and creativity through a virtual mirror created of online communication archives
 How to promote your own cool ideas through viral marketing on the Internet by finding and creating virtual tribes
 How you can become the creator of your own innovation teams and tribes
 How to measure and increase your own happiness using the “happimeter”, a body sensing device based on smartwatches
考核方式 Evaluation
The final grade is based on active participation and a final report based on the coolhunting and/or coolfarming assignment with Condor.

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Recent developments in artificial intelligence and the proliferation of the Internet of Things make it possible to harness the intelligence and creativity of huge numbers of people, connected in many different ways and on a much larger scale than has ever been possible before. Global but highly targeted and focused online social networks – virtual tribes – open up unprecedented opportunities to read and predict the collective mind, discovering emergent trends while they are still being hatched by small groups of creative individuals.
This seminar shows how to measure and track collective consciousness both within organizations, and globally on the Internet using social media analysis. It builds on the concept of swarm creativity and Collaborative Innovation Networks (COINs). COINs are self-organizing teams of intrinsically motivated innovators, collaborating over the Internet to create new things. The workshop combines latest insights from social media monitoring, machine learning, and big data with cutting-edge research in happiness and behavioral economics. It introduces the concept of “coolhunting” in three information spheres, the crowd – mostly found on Twitter (or Sina Weibo), the experts – found on blogs and Web sites, and the swarm – on Wikipedia and in online forums. It also shows how to do “coolfarming”, tracking and supporting the creation of COINs in organizations by analyzing individual interaction, e-mail and other communication archives and providing a mirror of their communication patterns to users. The goal is to improve communication, leading to better collaboration, leading to more innovation, creativity, and happiness.

The degree of collaboration can be measured through seven honest signals of collaboration, strong leadership, balanced contribution, rotating leadership, responsiveness, honest sentiment, shared language, and social capital. These signals can be used for “social quantum physics”, to measure and support entanglement in teams, and the Heisenberg effect of teams, to analyze how the behavior of a group changes, if it is mirrored back its behavior. The seminar explains how to implement these concepts using the software tool Condor, developed by the lecturer and his team at MIT. Condor calculates the seven honest signals of collaboration, tracking the degree of collective consciousness on online social media such as Twitter, blogs, or Facebook, or corporate e-mail, calendar, and chat archives using dynamic semantic social network analysis and machine learning.

The workshop also introduces the “happimeter”, an innovative body-sensing device based on smartwatches. The happimeter correlates the body signals of the wearer with her/his mood states and external outcomes such as creativity, team success, or organizational performance. During the workshop, participants will wear a happimeter to learn about their own mood states, to better understand what makes them happy, stressed, or more creative. While wearing the happimeter, they will do exercises and small group tasks. The goal is to identify predictors of individual happiness and of collaborative teams, with the goal of making individuals happier, and groups more creative and collaborative.

教学目的要求
Course Goals
The theme of this course is how to enhance creativity for innovation. The first goal is that the students understand the main theories and successful cases of innovation that created new value in society. The second goal is that the students master some methods of systems thinking and knowledge management so that they are able to think about how to link their own research to innovation.
Lecture Method
The course consists of five chapters, and one chapter is completed in four 50-minute lectures. In the first three lectures, the background of each chapter, major theories and application cases are explained. In the last hour of each Chapter, the students will be asked to write reports to confirm the content of the lecture.
Course Contents
First of all, with regard to innovation with economic achievements, its definition and some prominent theories will be lectured. Next, after methods for creating discontinuous ideas are outlined, design thinking and systems thinking, which are recently drawing attention, will be explained in detail. Then in Chapter 3 and 4, knowledge management methodologies in system science and knowledge science will be lectured. Finally, the knowledge construction systems theory that combines systems thinking and knowledge management, which this lecturer has been studying, will be introduced.

第二章 思路类问题（4课时，周元主讲）
思路类问题是指由于思路不对、方向错误等所导致的一类科技政策研究问题，例如对我国基础研究投入强度的争论、增长速度下降对就业的影响、新疆局势的基本判断等。本章内容包括问题特征、相关案例、方法应用等。
第三章 逻辑类问题（4课时，周元主讲）
逻辑类问题是指由于逻辑混乱等所导致的一类科技政策研究问题，例如“强化企业技术创新主体地位”的提法、经济科技“两张皮”与企业研发投入比例等。本章内容包括问题特征、相关案例、方法应用等。
第四章 训练类问题（4课时，周元主讲）
训练类问题是指由于缺乏基本训练和知识学习所导致的一类科技政策研究问题，例如关于“民生科技”的争论、对于“国家创新体系”的理解等。本章内容包括问题特征、相关案例、方法应用等。

意识类问题是指由于缺乏敏感的判断意识所导致的人云亦云、“正确的废话”一类的科技政策研究问题，例如充斥于各类媒体的各种科技政策研究文章。本章内容包括问题特征、相关案例、方法应用等。

本课程旨在引导研究生了解知识产权管理及活用的战略思考，提升研究生的国际视野。。
知识产权的管理牵涉甚广，除受政府政策影响外，法律制度、商业模式、专业人才、技术信息等都是经营管理知识产权所必须面临的课题，国际间因各国发逹程度不同，在知识产权的管理策略也有极大的差异，我国在倡导自主创新、科技强国、人才兴国并面向国际的时刻，对相关发逹国家之作法也应有一定之关注。
本课程将由宏观之角度带领研究生了解国际知识产权之趋势，继而去认识主要知识产权项目之管理运用及战略布局，例如由专利、商标、著作权、商业秘密等各方面在分述国内外之作法，并引相关成败之案例做实务之印证，俾使同学于修业完成后，对知识产权战略观点具备初步分析及应对之能力。

主要内容
内容提要：
中国现代作家系列人物之一：老舍之死与口述历史

1966年8月的一天，人们在北京的太平湖发现了老舍的尸体。但时至今日，老舍之死始终沉于历史的迷雾。随着时间推移，人们对老舍之死的描述不知不觉正在故事化着，甚至有时不失神话化了。本课程试图透过口述历史追踪老舍之死的历史谜团，并对作家老舍进行学术诠释。



中国现代作家系列人物之二： 戏里戏外说《茶馆》

老舍话剧《茶馆》与曹禺话剧《雷雨》被誉为中国现代话剧艺术的并立双峰。老舍何以能写出《茶馆》？北京人艺话剧舞台上的《茶馆》是怎样的？读者和观众又该怎样解读和欣赏《茶馆》？本课程将作出解答。



中国现代作家系列人物之三：“人间四月天”：徐志摩的诗歌与人生

“新月派”诗人徐志摩被誉为中国的雪莱。他从硖石走向世界，他的诗人生涯始于英国剑桥，剑桥给他注入艺术的性灵和爱的灵魂。他的人生理想是：“我将在茫茫人海中寻访我灵魂唯一之伴侣，得之，我幸；不得，我命。”《再别康桥》是他的标签之作。1931年，因飞机失事，以34岁华年“吻火”而亡。本课程将讲述志摩的诗歌、美文，及其与张幼仪、林徽因、凌叔华、陆小曼的婚姻、情感和爱情纠葛。



中国现代作家系列人物之四：萧乾：一个未带地图的旅人

萧乾，从一个蒙族平民家庭的穷小子，成为作家、翻译家、记者、报人，这其中充满传奇。他最具传奇色彩的人生经历，是在第二次世界大战期间，成为极少数中国驻欧战地记者之一，他的二战特写被誉为“欧洲发展史重要的见证”。他的人生箴言是：“我要在光怪陆离的大千世界做一个不带地图的旅人，我要采访人生。”本课程将讲述萧乾的文学创作及其传奇的记者生涯。

教学目的要求
一、通过诗歌参证历史或通过历史印证诗歌，寻找诗中的文化、文化中的诗。文学不仅在短短的方寸之间为我们展示了过去的琼楼玉宇，逼真地复制了那在过去岁月中也许早已为人们淡忘了的生动具体的细节，而且还为我们塑造了一个活生生的人群，一种生活的韵味，一片奇妙的风光。不习之，何以知之？
　　　二、诗歌能培养诗人的才情、哲人的思辩、历史学家的深沉。经典诗词可以使现代人在物欲横流而灵魂放逐的年代有一块属于自己的精神家园，并可以在其中诗意栖居。
　　　三、“一代有一代之文学”，从上古的神话到明清小说，每一个朝代都有其独领风骚的文学作品和文学现象，方今盛世，我们正应当将这些宝贵精神财富继承与传承下去。

教学目的要求
这门课主要介绍美国第二次世界大战以后的社会政治、外交关系的演化，重点有两个：一个是冷战，另一个是民权运动，二者塑造、改变了美国社会，而且二者之间有极大的关联。这门课从杜鲁门到奥巴马，研究内容包括原子弹的制造和使用、冷战的开启、朝鲜战争、麦卡锡主义、苏联卫星升天的冲击、民权运动、越南战争、妇女运动、环保运动、冷战结束、计算机网络和生物新技术兴起、9/11恐怖袭击及其后果、气候变化、奥巴马的当选、经济大衰退的影响等。我们关注的问题包括：国际政治和国内政治如何互相影响？技术是美国当代史的主要驱动力吗？美国从1945 到2014年有那些变化、又有哪些没有变化？我们的主要学习方式为课下阅读和写作、课上讲演、讨论、视频，以求获得没够近代史的知识，并改进批判性思维、写作和口头交流的能力。

课程简介：本课程是一个压缩性的两周短课程，研究美国近现代科技，包括科技政策，从19世纪末到21世纪初的历史发展,尤其注重在美国和世界史的广阔背景下来研究科技与社会的互动。内容包括：19世纪末二十世纪初美国工业化革命和各项技术发明，包括电灯，电话，和汽车的涌现及其社会文化影响，以及爱迪生，贝尔，福特等发明家的研究；二十世纪二十年代美国科学，尤其是物理学的崛起；二次世界大战中的科技，尤其是原子弹的研制和使用；冷战时期的科技政策，包括核军备竞赛，奥本海默案件，苏联卫星的影响，总统科学顾问委员会的兴衰，阿波罗登月计划等；现代环保运动的兴起，从卡逊的《寂静的春天》到全球变暖；尼克松访华以后中美科技教育交流；二十世纪末二十一世纪初的科技发展，尤其是信息技术—计算机和网络—和生物技术的发展和所引起的影响和争论；911和反恐战争对科技政策的影响；奥巴马的科技政策。贯穿这些案例的分析主题有：在美国近代史上，科学，技术与社会是什么样的关系？科学家在政府政策里起到了什么样的作用？社会对科技发展持什么样的态度：乐观，悲观，谨慎存疑？



课程主要用英文进行，包括讲演，讨论，教科书和其他阅读资料，播放的纪录片等。课程的主要教科书是 Thomas Hughes, American Genesis.因课程的压缩性，学生需要能够在短时间内进行大量的英文资料的阅读，并进行大量的英文写作练习。课程末期学生需要参加一个课堂考试和并提交一篇课外短文。课程的目的：上完这门课，学生应该对美国近现代科技发展的历史和现状有一个比较完整的了解，能够发展自己的批判性思维能力，能够改进自己英文口语和写作能力，能够比较熟悉如何使用英文原始文献和研究文献。
